div.div: Correlation between the two methods for calculation of detectability.
div.p: Correlation between the two methods for calculation of detectability. Whiskers are 95% confidence intervals calculated only for Royle’s estimator [ 30]. Spearman correlation coefficient is presented.
(TIF)
Click here for additional data file.

div.div: Correlation between bird body size and detectability.
div.p: Correlation between bird body length and the estimator of detectability (Royle estimator[ 30]). Whiskers are 95% confidence intervals. Spearman correlation coefficient is presented.
(TIF)
Click here for additional data file.

div.div: Correlation between the observed number of bird species and estimated number of species.
div.p: Correlation between the observed number of bird species and estimated number of species via bias-corrected Chao estimation [ 26, 27]for rural environment during December (a) and January (b), and for urban one (c, d). Spearman correlation coefficients are presented.
(TIF)
Click here for additional data file.

div.div: Correlation between the observed abundance of birds and estimated abundance.
div.p: Correlation between the observed abundance of birds and estimated abundance via Royle’s correction [ 30] for rural environment during December (a) and January (b), and for urban environment (c, d). Spearman correlation coefficients are presented.
(TIF)
Click here for additional data file.

div.div: Principal component analysis on habitat cover variables.
div.p: Ordination environmental variables describing cover of different habitat types along axes representing first two principal components (PCA).
(TIF)

div.div: Location and details of the 26 urban environments (towns and cities); data extracted from www.wikipedia.org.
div.p: Cities are arranged by human population size.

div.div: Spearman correlation coefficients between environmental variables.
div.p: Significant correlations are emboldened (significance level is in brackets).

div.div: Estimation of random effects in GLMMs.
div.p: (DOC)
Click here for additional data file.

div.div: Generalized linear mixed models (GLMM) describing the species richness of birds in urban and rural areas during winter.
div.p: The Akaike information criterion score (AICc), the -2log, difference between the given model and the most parsimonious model (Δ) and the Akaike weight (w) are listed. Explanation of variable codes: Month—month of survey (December vs. January), Environment—type of environment (urban vs. rural), Longitude—geographical longitude, Latitude—geographical latitude, PCA1—a first principal component of environmental variables describing the increasing cover of open agricultural habitats, PCA2—a second principal component of environmental variables describing the gradient from natural grasslands (meadows) to intensively managed amenity grassland, Feeders—number of bird feeders in a square plot, CitySize—human population size in the city. The best model is emboldened.
(DOC)
Click here for additional data file.

div.div: Generalized linear mixed models (GLMM) describing the abundance of birds in urban and rural areas during winter.
div.p: The Akaike information criterion score (AICc), the -2log, difference between the given model and the most parsimonious model (Δ) and the Akaike weight (w) are listed. Explanation of variable codes: Month—month of survey (December vs. January), Environment—type of environment (urban vs. rural), Longitude—geographical longitude, Latitude—geographical latitude, PCA1—a first principal component of environmental variables describing the increasing cover of open agricultural habitats, PCA2—a second principal component of environmental variables describing the gradient from natural grasslands (meadows) to intensively managed amenity grassland, Feeders—number of bird feeders in a square plot, CitySize—human population size in the city. The best model is emboldened.

div.div: Generalized linear mixed models (GLMM) describing the Gini-Simpson bird diversity index in urban and rural areas during winter.
div.p: The Akaike information criterion score (AICc), the -2log, difference between the given model and the most parsimonious model (Δ) and the Akaike weight ( w) are listed. Explanation of variable codes: Month—month of survey (December vs. January), Environment—type of environment (urban vs. rural), Longitude—geographical longitude, Latitude—geographical latitude, PCA1—a first principal component of environmental variables describing the increasing cover of open agricultural habitats, PCA2—a second principal component of environmental variables describing the gradient from natural grasslands (meadows) to intensively managed amenity grassland, Feeders—number of bird feeders in a square plot, CitySize—human population size in the city. The best models are emboldened.
